text:
Raskolnikov only snapped back to reality when he found himself in the next street. He looked around and saw he was right next to a tavern with steps leading down from the pavement. Just then, two drunk guys stumbled out, arguing and leaning on each other as they climbed the steps. Without thinking, Raskolnikov headed down the steps. He had never been in a tavern before, but now he felt dizzy and super thirsty. He craved a cold beer and figured his weakness was due to not eating.

He plopped down at a sticky little table in a dark, grimy corner, ordered a beer, and gulped down the first glass. Instantly, he felt better, and his thoughts started to clear up. 

"All this is nonsense," he told himself, feeling hopeful. "There’s nothing to stress about! It’s just physical exhaustion. A glass of beer, some dry bread—and boom! My brain feels stronger, my mind clearer, and my will is solid! Phew, how trivial all this is!" 

But even with that confident thought, he felt cheerful, as if a huge weight had been lifted off him. He glanced around the room, feeling friendly towards the few people there. Yet, deep down, he sensed that this sudden happiness wasn’t quite normal.

The tavern was pretty empty. Besides the two drunk guys he saw earlier, a group of five men and a girl with a concertina had just left. Their exit left the place quiet and a bit desolate. The remaining folks in the tavern were...

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov, feeling giddy and tormented by thirst, enters a tavern for the first time, seeking solace in beer to clear his mind.
